title: SELECTING N-LOWEST SCORES FOR TRAINING MOS PREDICTION MODELS
author: Yuto Kondo (NTT Corporation, Japan), Hirokazu Kameoka (NTT Corporation, Japan), Kou Tanaka (NTT Corporation, Japan), Takuhiro Kaneko (NTT Corporation, Japan), ...
relevance_why: The proposed Nlow-MOS metric introduces a novel approach to speech quality assessment that could be relevant for improving audio and speech processing systems in Haohe's research.
background: The study proposes a new method for predicting speech quality, focusing on low-quality segments in audio data to derive a more representative mean opinion score (MOS).
contribution: This paper introduces N-lowest mean opinion score (Nlow-MOS) to solve the inconsistency in human ratings for speech quality, achieving improved performance in prediction accuracy metrics.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily relied on regular mean opinion score (MOS) which aggregates all human ratings, leading to potential bias from higher scores on better segments.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances prediction by selectively using the lowest ratings, which are suggested to better reflect overall perceived quality.

key_innovation: The key innovation lies in the use of Nlow-MOS as a training target for neural models, which emphasizes more reliable low-quality evaluations over average scores.
real_world_impact: By improving the accuracy of speech quality predictors, this method could lead to better speech synthesis systems and enhanced user experiences in TTS and voice conversion applications.
limitations: The paper does not explicitly mention limitations.

new_terms.N-lowest mean opinion score (Nlow-MOS): **N-lowest mean opinion score (Nlow-MOS)** is the average of the N lowest ratings assigned to speech samples, aimed at providing a more robust measure of subjective quality.
